intro: Cracca polysperma, commonly known as the common cracca, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, with finely divided, fern-like leaves. Its small, yellowish flowers are clustered in umbels, a typical feature of the Apiaceae family. Cracca polysperma is often found in grassy areas and along roadsides, and it is known for its medicinal properties.
